passages.text: Retail Retail - Non Food

It is good to be back after a few weeks' holiday- inspired absence. This has been another lively week in the European discretionary space. We have been taking a more constructive stance on Luxury post the 1H results and investors have been wanting to see some evidence of a better luxury consumer. China was always set to improve largely based on easier comparatives from last year in 3Q but it still helps to have companies confirming this. And in our view, the US tariff impact on luxury was always likely to be less impactful than what other sectors experience, but the \(39\%\) Swiss tariff still had the risk of some "sticker shock" on pricing. We would like to see some additional commentary on price elasticity to back up the Swatch comments, but the positive trading comments are supportive - and reflect what we believe investors wanted to hear to justify delving back in to the Luxury sector.

In Retail we updated our view on the UK to a more cautious consumer outlook with our expectation that growth in discretionary spending power is set to fade by 4ppt from \(7\%\) in 1H to \(3\%\) in 2H. Consumer confidence has been bouncing around at low levels but as we look into the end of the year, there are concerns about the impact of the budget - but more importantly, in our opinion, the increase in unemployment and fear of higher inflation.

This week saw the Luxury sector up \(3 - 5\%\) on the week aided by positive Swatch commentary with Burberry \(+5\%\) the best performer and Hermes up only \(+1\%\) Swatch flat, WOSG and Pandora \(- 2\%\) at the weaker end. In Retail the sector was down \(- 2 - 4\%\) with Puma the standout at \(+12\%\) (on news articles suggesting that Artemis may be trying to divest its c. \(30\%\) stake to a trade buyer), JD Sports \(+4\%\) (on better- than- expected results), Inditex \(+2\%\) and B&M and Currys largely flat. At the weaker end Wicks and ASOS were down \(- 9\%\) , Kingfisher \(- 8\%\) and AB Foods \(- 6\%\) with the risks to the UK consumer fading.

It is still a relatively quiet reporting period with only Currys set to update on its 1Q trading with the AGM; we expect a moderation in LFL growth against tough companies with \(+1.5\%\) UK LFL and \(+2\%\) Nordics LFL. In the UK Currys may start seeing the tougher consumer environment and it will be interesting to hear any commentary they have for the outlook.
Adam Cochrane Research Analyst +44- 20- 754- 17812
Alison Lygo Research Analyst +44- 20- 754- 11724
Benjamin Yokong- Zoega Research Analyst +44- 20- 754- 12338
Do- Hyun Yoo Research Associate +44- 20- 754- 19487
Shwetha Ramachandran Research Associate
Figure 1:Macro data highlights of the week

We took a more cautious stance on the UK consumer at the beginning of the week and most investors generally agreed with the risk from higher unemployment and increased inflation on consumer confidence. The main areas of pushback were on the higher savings rate, which may provide a cushion (potentially amongst the higher income consumers but fear of unemployment generally drives the higher savings) and whether the "budget fear" may be similar to 2024 where there was no immediate impact on spending with a stronger- than- expected 4Q performance (the main difference this year is rising inflation and falling employment levels). The messaging from companies is almost uniformly cautious on UK spending, which may reflect a degree of understandable caution. It does appear that leisure spending is being prioritised to a greater degree – with music concerts and summer holiday spending seeing no signs of a slowdown. This may see slightly more subdued retail spending as consumers start to look towards Christmas.

Swatch suggested that they will not be absorbing any of the \(39\%\) US tariff and that a further \(5 - 10\%\) price increase (in addition to \(3 - 8\%\) already taken) will be sufficient to maintain profitability and they think there is limited price elasticity. With regards to current trading, they pointed out that in July US sales were up \(19\%\) and expect August to be up \(c.20\%\) with Mexico and Canada strong as well. Although not quantified, management suggested that China was doing better but from a low level and Hong Kong is improving as well. We believe investors have been wanting to become more bullish on the Luxury sector as we look at a sequential improvement in 2H on 1H, and the positive data points likely reinforce this view more than a negative data point will dent the view. The sector sentiment is shifting, which suggests that earnings downgrades are no longer expected, and just hitting numbers for 3Q is likely to be enough at this stage to maintain the momentum.

The value of small parcels from China to the UK more than doubled in 2024 to over £3bn, which accounts for \(c.50\%\) of the total small parcels shipped into the UK. There are proposals in the EU to introduce a "handling charge" per parcel and the UK is reviewing the customs treatment. In the US the removal of the de- minimis exemption for packages under \(800 has created a number of problems in the implementation but is likely to slow the growth from the Chinese discount retailers. Whilst an incremental £1.5bn of sales is small compared to the overall £220bn UK non- food retail sales, it does account for all of the £1.5bn sales growth in the market. The categories for this £1.5bn increase are not disclosed, but we suspect there will be a larger impact in clothing and smaller household items. In our coverage there has been a clear impact on the lower- price- point retailers such as Primark and B&M but likely there has been a degree of impact across the board.
The recent Bloomberg article suggesting that Artemis may put its Puma stake up for sale is not surprising in itself for a number of reasons: 1) Artemis has debt that has
29 August 2025 Retail - Non Food General Retail & Luxury Weekly

to be managed, especially against the backdrop of a smaller dividend from Kering, and 2) there may well be some frustration with Puma's performance and share price development. We do find the timing slightly perplexing in that Artemis has an influential seat on the board and a new CEO has been appointed but is yet to announce the full strategy (to be announced with the 3Q in October). Trying to sell a large investment before the new strategy has been announced feels slightly unusual in terms of timing. From an investor point of view, there could be some upside from a potential trade buyer if an offer were to be incoming; there has been an uptick in brand acquisitions at depressed valuations in the last year. We think the Puma brand could benefit from a reset and realigning its distribution with the customer perception of the brand.

We expect Currys to have seen a moderation in LFL growth in the UK, as it begins to annualise the \(+5\%\) LFL comparative, which we expect found support from sporting events last summer. We also note the slowdown in consumer spending data evident in Barclaycard data (May- 2%, June- 5% July- 4.3%). We model for \(1.5\%\) UK LFL growth which reflects continued market share gains. In the Nordics, we model LFL \(+2\%\) , in line with 2H- 24 and against a \(- 2\%\) LFL comparative and look for signs of an encouraging Nordics consumer.

We expect Dunelm to report FY25 PBT of £210m and EPS of 77p (in line with cons). Dunelm have already reported their FY25 trading update with sales \(+3.8\%\) to £1,771m. Management expect gross margin up \(+60bps\) to \(52.4\%\) (DBe 52.4%) and PBT margin broadly stable yoy at c. \(12\%\) (DBe 11.9%). Within EBIT, the better gross margin is helping to offset higher opex inflation. We expect opex opex/sales up \(+70bps\) yoy to \(40\%\) , resulting in EBIT of £220m with \(12.5\%\) margin (- 10bps yoy). As we look to FY26, we anticipate Dunelm's strong product proposition to drive continued LFL (+c. \(3\%\) ) supported by new store openings (+c. \(3\%\) ). We see gross margin tailwinds from freight, FX and input costs. Back- end- loaded store openings was a small EBIT margin drag in Q4. We expect opex inflation to moderate through FY26 with slowing wage growth, which we expect to drive a slight margin recovery.

Key debates: (1) The extent to which there was a weather- related pull forward in Dunelm's Q4 (Apr- Jun) and if current trading is subsequently slowing, (2) Strategic progress following the Home Focus and Designers Guild acquisitions, (3) Update from the incoming CEO (effective 1st Oct), (4) The impact from freight / FX on gross margin and opex deleverage, (5) Store expansion plans including small formats.

We expect Inditex to report 1H sales of £18,485m (cons £18,543m) up \(+2.3\%\) with EBIT of £3,531m (cons £3,571m) and EPS of £0.91 (cons £0.91). For 2Q we forecast cFX sales growth of \(+6\%\) given the \(+6\%\) growth in the first 5 weeks (implying a \(+6\%\) growth for the remainder of the period). We forecast gross margin down - 30bps to \(56.2\%\) given slightly higher promotions due to the weak start to the season and initial impact from US tariffs. Given the impact of a stronger EUR and we expect opex/sales to decline by - 35bps to give a 70bps decline in EBIT margin to \(18.5\%\) and £1,890m EBIT (cons £1,942m) and EPS of £0.49, up \(+3.8\%\) yoy. For the trading update on July and early August, we are looking for a \(+6\%\) cFX sales performance broadly in line with 2Q, which is slightly below consensus \(+7\%\) .
29 August 2025Retail - Non FoodGeneral Retail & Luxury Weekly

Key debates: 1) Inditex has seen the negative earnings momentum halted in the last month but EPS growth has now fallen to MSD- HSD% range, which may challenge the c.23x Cal 25E PE, especially if there is renewed interest in the Luxury sector. 2) The impact of negative FX translation on gross margin and opex deleverage; 3) A discussion of the potential US tariff impact seen so far and pricing decisions being taken to offset this; 4) Whether the slower cFX sales growth in 2Q is related to weather and other factors that may be highlighted by the geographic performance split.

German retail sales increased by \(1.9\%\) yoy in July, a slowdown from June's \(+4.9\%\) and missing the market's \(2.6\%\) forecast. Monthly sales declined by \(1.5\%\) in July, contrasting with June's \(1\%\) growth and falling below the expected \(- 0.4\%\) .

Retail sales rebounded in July, increasing by \(+4.8\%\) yoy, up from \(+2.1\%\) in June. This was driven by strong growth in sales of furniture, electronics and household appliances \((+13.8\%\) vs \(12.7\%\) L3M) and textiles, clothing and footwear \((+13.2\%\) vs \(+6.6\%\) L3M). The improved retail environment is attributed to lower inflation, a steady labor market, and decreasing interest rates.

Asda's income tracker, which measures weekly family income after essential spending and taxes, shows aggregate discretionary income growth slowing \((+3.7\%\) yoy in July vs. \(+7.5\%\) L6M). Disposable income fell for \(60\%\) of UK households in July. Notably, middle- income households experienced their first decline in two years \((- 1.6\%)\) , while lower- income households continued to see a significant drop in spending power \((- 11\%)\) . This decline is largely due to rising inflation, particularly for essential goods. That said, higher- income households are seeing improving spending power and account for the majority of discretionary income growth in recent years.

France consumer confidence fell to 87 (from 89 in July) in August, below the expected 89. This drop represents the lowest confidence level recorded since October 2023, largely due to escalating concerns about the economic outlook and unemployment.

Spain retail sales grew by \(+4.7\%\) yoy in July 2025, a deceleration vs June's \(+6.2\%\) . This deceleration was primarily due to slower growth in services \((3.2\%\) vs. \(4.6\%\) ), despite stronger performance in auto & parts \((7.3\%\) vs. \(7.1\%\) ) and food, beverages & tobacco \((5.1\%\) vs. \(3.8\%\) ). Seasonally adjusted retail turnover declined by \(0.4\%\) sequentially, marking the first monthly drop since January, following \(+1.1\%\) in June.
Figure 2: Spain Retail sales growth decelerated in July

Swatch Gains as CEO Hayek Eases Concerns Over US Tariffs: Swatch Group's stock soared after CEO Nick Hayek assured investors that the US watch market is robust, despite tariffs. Analysts confirm Swatch's plans for further US price increases to offset these tariffs. Hayek also provided a positive outlook for North American sales and indicated a slow recovery in China, leading to gains across the luxury watch sector. (Bloomberg)

New M&S warehouse forms part of £340m investment: Marks & Spencer is investing £340 million in its food supply chain, including building a massive 1.3 million sq ft national distribution center at DIRFT, Northamptonshire, by 2029. This project aims to double M&S's food business capacity and create over 1,000 permanent jobs. Local officials praise the investment as a boost for the region's strong logistics sector. (Bloomberg)

France's Pinault Family Reportedly Eyeing Puma Sale, Options: The Pinault family, owners of Groupe Artémis, are reportedly considering selling their 29% stake in Puma, among other options. They have reportedly engaged with potential buyers, including US sportswear companies and Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds, though a deal is not guaranteed. (Bloomberg)

China's Anta Sports Denies Reports It Plans to Buy Canada Goose: Anta Sports has denied reports of its involvement in a potential acquisition of Canada Goose. While Bain Capital has reportedly received multiple offers for Canada Goose, valued at \(1.4 billion, from various private equity firms and other companies (including conjecture of Anta Sports in a consortium), Anta Sports has officially distanced itself from such a deal. Despite general Chinese interest in acquiring Canada Goose, no agreements have been reached. (Bloomberg)

The Equity Rating Dispersion Chart depicts the following:

The proportion of recommendations that are rated "buy", "sell" and "hold" over the previous 12 months. This is shown for securities issued in the stated region e.g. "Europe Universe". See rating definitions below. This is represented by the "Companies Covered" bars in the chart. The percentage value displayed above the bar is the proportion as a percentage. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "buy" / "Companies Covered" bar means that \(50\%\) of DB's equity research covered companies over the past 12 months have a "buy" rating.
Next to each of the three respective bars showing the proportion of "buy", "sell" and "hold" recommendations we provide two additional bars to show:

- The proportion of "buy", "sell" or "hold recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates provided MIFID Investment or Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. This is represented in the "MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the given rating where DB has also provided MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated have also received MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services from DB.

- The proportion of "buy" (or "sell" or "hold) recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates has provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months for which it has received compensation. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the stated rating where DB has also provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ Investment Banking relationship" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated also have an Investment Banking Relationship with DB.
Buy: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors buy the stock.
Sell: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors sell the stock.
Hold: We take a neutral view on the stock 12- months out and, based on this time horizon, do not recommend either a Buy or Sell.
\(\mathsf{TSR} =\) Total Shareholder Return. Percentage change in share price from current price to projected target price plus projected dividend yield

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.

Backtested, hypothetical or simulated performance results have inherent limitations. Unlike an actual performance record based on trading actual client portfolios, simulated results are achieved by means of the retroactive application of a backtested model itself designed with the benefit of hindsight. Taking into account historical events the backtesting of performance also differs from actual account performance because an actual investment strategy may be adjusted any time, for any reason, including a response to material, economic or market factors. The backtested performance includes hypothetical results that do not reflect the reinvestment of dividends and other earnings or the deduction of advisory fees, brokerage or other commissions, and any other expenses that a client would have paid or actually paid. No representation is made that any trading strategy or account will or is likely to achieve profits or losses similar to those shown. Alternative modeling techniques or assumptions might produce significantly different results and prove to be more appropriate. Past hypothetical backtest results are neither an indicator nor guarantee of future returns. Actual results will vary, perhaps materially, from the analysis.

The method for computing individual E,S,G and composite ESG scores set forth herein is a novel method developed by the Research department within Deutsche Bank AG, computed using a systematic approach without human intervention. Different data providers, market sectors and geographies approach ESG analysis and incorporate the findings in a variety of ways. As such, the ESG scores referred to herein may differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other ESG data providers in the market and may also differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other divisions within the Deutsche Bank Group. Such ESG scores also differ from other ratings and rankings that have historically been applied in research reports published by Deutsche Bank AG. Further, such ESG scores do not represent a formal or official view of Deutsche Bank AG. It should be noted that the decision to incorporate ESG factors into any investment strategy may inhibit the ability to participate in certain investment opportunities that otherwise would be consistent with your investment objective and other principal investment strategies. The returns on a portfolio consisting primarily of sustainable investments may be lower or higher than portfolios where ESG factors, exclusions, or other sustainability issues are not considered, and the investment opportunities available to such portfolios may differ. Companies may not necessarily meet high performance standards on all aspects of ESG or sustainable investing issues; there is also no guarantee that any company will meet expectations in connection with corporate responsibility, sustainability, and/or impact performance.
